author: By Christina Caron
title: Identifying Red Flags at the Ob-Gyn
description: For most women, the visit is routine and uneventful. But recent accusations of sexual misconduct have raised questions about how best to protect patients.
content: This story was originally published on Jan. 22, 2020 on NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Sole-Smith
title: Navigating Thanksgiving With Your Picky Eater
description: Why it’s really O.K. if your child eats only rolls (again) this year.
content: This story was originally published on Nov. 18, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul L. Underwood
title: Are My Kid’s Tantrums Abnormal?
description: If your toddler’s meltdowns are atypically frequent or intense, there might be something more going on.
content: This guide was originally published on Dec. 10, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Hobson
title: Peeing Your Pants After Pregnancy Is Preventable
description: Stress urinary incontinence may be a side effect of giving birth, but several treatment options can help clear it up.
content: This guide was originally published on Oct. 17, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Sohn
title: How to Handle Your Baby’s Stay in the NICU
description: Baby’s visit to the NICU can stress out parents, but there are a few ways to cope.
content: This guide was originally published on May 17, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: From Missing Persons to Mistaken Identities, Books About Seeing and Being Seen
description: Slices of young adult life, from Monica Hesse (“They Went Left”), Ismée Williams (“This Train Is Being Held”), George M. Johnson (“All Boys Aren’t Blue”) and Meredith Tate (“The Last Confession of Autumn Casterly”).
content: There are scores of novels about World War II, but far fewer about what happened next. When we meet Zofia Lederman in August 1945 in Monica Hesse’s THEY WENT LEFT (Little, Brown, 364 pp., $17.99; ages 14 and up), she has spent her adolescence surviving the Birkenau and Gross-Rosen concentration camps. But as her liberators celebrate the end of a nightmarish era, Zofia can’t seem to join in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Yu and Austin Ramzy
title: Amid Pandemic, Hong Kong Arrests Major Pro-Democracy Figures
description: Rarely have so many prominent pro-democracy figures — over a dozen — been arrested at once. The arrests signaled a broader crackdown on the antigovernment movement that roiled the semiautonomous city last year.
content: HONG KONG — More than a dozen leading pro-democracy activists and former lawmakers in Hong Kong were arrested on Saturday in connection with the protests that raged in the city last year, the biggest roundup of prominent opposition figures in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: A New Chapter in Salt Lake City
description: Nicholaus Shackleton and Eric Johnson met from afar on a dating app. Eventually Mr. Shackleton moved from Seattle to Utah to be with Mr. Johnson.
content: Nicholaus Shackleton, 39, met Eric Johnson, 37, in October 2017 while halfheartedly looking on the men’s dating app Scruff, while he was away for the weekend in Denver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: 'Within 5 or 10 Minutes, I Was in Love’
description: The couple matched on Tinder in 2015, had their first date that very evening and were in love before the night was done.
content: Tara Mancini was separated and living in suburban New Jersey when Tinder matched her in 2015 with Peter Goldring. They chatted a bit through the app and then agreed to meet for dinner in New York that same evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Heard-Garris, M.D
title: Your 3-Month-Old
description: Lights, camera, action! At 3 months, your baby is becoming more photo-ready. You may capture your baby giving you a smile and lifting her head to see the camera. She may seem to be more responsive, copying some of your expressions and trying to babble through a conversation with you. If you have had a trying first two months with your baby, in terms of sleep and fussiness, you may be in luck. Your baby may now sleep for longer periods (stretches of seven to eight hours) and, if she was fussy, she might even be beginning to calm down. Now that you’ve made it to 3 months, hopefully you and your baby can really come alive.
content: This story was originally published on April 23, 2019 on NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Vote for Biden? Sanders Supporters Say It’s ‘Up in the Air’
description: In interviews, some of Bernie Sanders’s primary voters saw Joe Biden as a weaker candidate than Hillary Clinton. Others didn’t think he could win. Nearly all were unenthusiastic.
content: Mary Shippee voted for Senator Bernie Sanders in Wisconsin’s Democratic primary this month, well after it was clear he had no chance to become the party’s presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Heard-Garris, M.D
title: Your 1-Year-Old
description: Welcome to toddlerhood! You are starting to have a mover and a shaker on your hands. The 1-year mark is a big milestone for your child, as well as for you: You survived one year as a parent. This is a time for even more growth, independence and exploration for your child, so you have to stay on your toes. As she grows physically, you will be impressed by the strides she is making developmentally.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan MacLean Weir, M.D
title: Your 4-Year-Old
description: Your 4-year-old is likely making great strides toward independence as he learns to complete certain tasks solo. As he masters new skills, it can be difficult not to hover and offer assistance, especially since a five-second chore all too often transforms into a 10-minute endeavor when young kids are left to their own devices. While there are likely times when you will be rushed and just need to put their shoes on for them (for the love of all that is holy), let your child help out whenever you can.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dodge
title: What to Know Before Adopting a Child
description: There are three main paths to adopting. The route you choose will be based on personal, legal and financial factors.
content: This guide was originally published on May 6, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Reslewic Keatley
title: Should You Circumcise Your Baby Boy?
description: Circumcision probably won’t impact your son’s health, research shows, but a range of cultural and social factors deserve your consideration.
content: This guide was originally published on July 12, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Can Landlords Get Relief if Their Tenants Can’t Pay?
description: As renters lose jobs and the economy remains dormant, landlords face tough choices and few options.
content: Q: I own a small Brooklyn apartment building with two residential units and a ground-floor commercial space. The business is temporarily closed because of the coronavirus shutdown, and both tenants have lost their jobs and are unable to pay rent. I don’t have a mortgage on the property, but I have to pay property taxes in July and utilities to maintain the building. I understand that these are terrible times, and agree that tenants should get rent relief. But what are landlords to do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Hunter Lopez
title: The Trouble With Amber Teething Necklaces
description: Experts have warned that this popular jewelry is not only ineffective at soothing a child’s pain, but is also dangerous. So why does the trend persist?
content: This story was originally published on July 23, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan MacLean Weir, M.D
title: Your 2-Year-Old
description: Two-year-olds have a bad reputation: they’re notoriously headstrong and prone to having temper tantrums in the snack aisle at the grocery store. But the “Terrible Twos,” on the whole, are not terrible at all. In fact, one of the great joys of parenting a 2-year-old is watching his knowledge expand every day. When his vocabulary doubles and then triples and, eventually, includes too many words to count, remember: You did that. You made those advances possible by talking with him even when you were tired, distracted or late for work. And as his communication skills explode, your child’s personality will become even more distinct. He’ll learn to sing along to your favorite songs and begin to laugh at jokes only the two of you understand.
content: By 2 years of age, your child should be on the move. If she has any motor delays, her pediatrician should have assessed and possibly referred her for additional services, such as physical therapy, by now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Heard-Garris, M.D
title: Your 3-Month-Old
description: Lights, camera, action! At 3 months, your baby is becoming more photo-ready. You may capture your baby giving you a smile and lifting her head to see the camera. She may seem to be more responsive, copying some of your expressions and trying to babble through a conversation with you. If you have had a trying first two months with your baby, in terms of sleep and fussiness, you may be in luck. Your baby may now sleep for longer periods (stretches of seven to eight hours) and, if she was fussy, she might even be beginning to calm down. Now that you’ve made it to 3 months, hopefully you and your baby can really come alive.
content: This story was originally published on April 23, 2019 on NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Officials Say C.D.C. Errors Caused Testing Delays
description: Democratic lawmakers and the Trump administration seek to break an impasse over a small-business loan program. Hospitals struggle to provide dialysis amid an unforeseen surge in patients with kidney failure.
content: Federal officials acknowledged on Saturday that sloppy laboratory practices at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention caused contamination that rendered the nation’s first coronavirus tests ineffective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wilson
title: The Seas as the Ultimate Coronavirus Isolation? Not. So. Fast.
description: Folks who live on boats face off with land they can’t set foot on, staring down logistical hurdles, ethical issues and social media harshness.
content: Simon and Carla Fowler are anchored in their catamaran about 650 feet off a deserted beach in the Bahamas, and they have a message for anyone locked down on land who wishes that they too could be self-isolating on the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Robert Gebeloff
title: How Millions of Women Became the Most Essential Workers in America
description: One in three jobs held by women has been designated as essential.
content: Every day, Constance Warren stands behind the cold cuts counter at a grocery store in New Orleans, watching the regular customers come and go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Ulet Ifansasti
title: Bought for a Song: An Indonesian Craze Puts Wild Birds at Risk
description: Songbirds are being entered into high-stakes singing competitions across the country, and conservationists say protected species are in danger.
content: CURUP, Indonesia — Hiding in the dense Sumatran jungle, the poacher chose a thin branch, coated it with homemade glue and played a snippet of birdsong on an old cellphone. Within moments, three tiny birds alighted on the branch and were trapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Coronavirus Halts Another U.K. Ritual: Birthday Gun Salute for Queen
description: Buckingham Palace said the queen had also instructed that flags not be flown in her honor unless it was done while observing social distancing.
content: LONDON — When Queen Elizabeth II turns 94 on Tuesday, for the first time in her nearly seven-decade reign her birthday will not be marked by a gun salute — another longstanding ritual lost to the grim siege of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Pharmacist Arrested in Plot to Firebomb a Rival to Sell More Drugs on the Dark Web
description: Hyrum T. Wilson of Auburn, Neb., conspired with a drug dealer to rob, then destroy a competitor’s pharmacy, according to federal prosecutors.
content: The list of supplies needed to rob and blow up the pharmacist’s competition was tucked in a black leather-bound notebook, prosecutors say: face masks, duffel bags, a rental car, a canister of gasoline and at least four firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Vote for Biden? Sanders Supporters Say It’s ‘Up in the Air’
description: In interviews, some of Bernie Sanders’s primary voters saw Joe Biden as a weaker candidate than Hillary Clinton. Others didn’t think he could win. Nearly all were unenthusiastic.
content: Mary Shippee voted for Senator Bernie Sanders in Wisconsin’s Democratic primary this month, well after it was clear he had no chance to become the party’s presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Need More Than Netflix? These 15 Short Films Are Worth Your Time
description: Here are some crowd-pleasing documentaries for short attention spans — and tight budgets. You can stream them right here.
content: Stuck at home and finished Netflix? These short documentaries are an instantaneous passport around the world. Go to Sundance and SXSW on your phone with our collection of Op-Docs from those festivals, or take in a number of Emmy- and Oscar- nominated films you can’t find anywhere else. Spend seven minutes, or an afternoon, while you see deep space in a way no one has before, be in the zone with Slomo, meet the original fourth member of the Black Eyed Peas. Want to watch more? Our collection of over 300 films is available to watch from anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hans Taparia
title: How Covid-19 Is Making Millions of Americans Healthier
description: People are finally cooking more.
content: Rachael Ray, Blue Apron and Michael Pollan all tried in their own ways. But Covid-19 has done what none of them could do.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Officials Say C.D.C. Errors Caused Testing Delays
description: Democratic lawmakers and the Trump administration seek to break an impasse over a small-business loan program. Hospitals struggle to provide dialysis amid an unforeseen surge in patients with kidney failure.

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Laetitia Vancon
title: With Broad, Random Tests for Antibodies, Germany Seeks Path Out of Lockdown
description: It was the first large Western democracy to contain the spread of the coronavirus and is now the first to methodically go about reopening its economy. Others are watching.
content: BERLIN — Felix Germann was not expecting anyone when his doorbell rang last week. Outside was a doctor who looked like she had just stepped out of an operating theater, green scrubs, face mask and all — and a policeman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: Conservatives Fuel Protests Against Coronavirus Lockdowns
description: In addition to the “You Can’t Close America” rally in Austin, Texas, on Saturday, modest demonstrations took place in the capitals of Nevada, Indiana and Maryland.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Dave Litrell stood at a socially un-distant length from his fellow protesters on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Are Face Masks the New Condoms?
description: If people with no symptoms are spreading the coronavirus, as some studies suggest, it may be time to give face masks the kind of advertising and promotion that support condoms as lifesavers.
content: Are face masks going to become like condoms — ubiquitous, sometimes fashionable, promoted with public service announcements? They should be, one virus researcher says, if early indications are correct in suggesting that Covid-19 is often spread by people who feel healthy and show no symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Get Child Support as a Single Parent

description: Intrauterine insemination is a fertility procedure that is typically quick and painless. But success rates can vary.

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: John Prine and ‘One World’
description: “Austin City Limits” airs a performance by John Prine, while celebrities come together in a special to support health care workers fighting the coronavirus.
content: AUSTIN CITY LIMITS 11 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). This live music show is resurfacing an episode from 2018 to honor the Grammy-winning folk singer-songwriter John Prine, who died of complications from the coronavirus on April 7 at the age of 73. Prine was revered by Bob Dylan, and in 2019, was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame. This performance, his eighth and final for “Austin City Limits,” came 40 years after he made his debut on the show in 1978. It features a few classics, such as “Illegal Smile,” off Prine’s debut record; “Lake Marie,” from 1995’s “Lost Dogs and Mixed Blessings,” and seven tracks from his final album, “The Tree of Forgiveness,” including “When I Get to Heaven.” It’s a joyful farewell, in which Prine makes peace with mortality and sings: “When I get to heaven, I’m gonna shake God’s hand/Thank him for more blessings than one man can stand/Then I’m gonna get a guitar and start a rock-n-roll band.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Your 2-Month-Old
description: At 2 months, there’s not much for your baby to do besides eat, sleep, poop and love (and be loved). Expectations should be low, and there are few things to look out for.
content: Control and strengthen body parts. At this age, your baby can likely lift her head and maybe even push herself up a little while lying on her stomach. She may also move her arms and legs more smoothly, open her hands spontaneously or hold on to an object (like a rattle).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Best in Class
description: Ryan McCarty chivies us around in his Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Just yesterday, we were gliding across the puzzle ice together like Torvill and Dean! Today’s Ryan McCarty construction was like clinging to the side of a mountain with an ice ax for me, or at least the southwest corner was. I was pretty slow and tentative through the interesting center as well, struggling with both of the triple stacks, horizontal and vertical. All six of those 11-word entries are debuts, by the way!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Economic Data Is About to Get Weird
description: Just when we need reliable information the most, the signals are likely to be muddled.
content: Our economic data wasn’t built for this.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Early Intervention Changed My Son’s Life
description: Free access to quality care accelerated his recovery after a prenatal stroke.

This live music show is resurfacing an episode from 2018 to honor the Grammy-winning folk singer-songwriter John Prine, who died of complications from the coronavirus on April 7 at the age of 73. Prine was revered by Bob Dylan, and in 2019, was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame. This performance, his eighth and final for “Austin City Limits,” came 40 years after he made his debut on the show in 1978. It features a few classics, such as “Illegal Smile,” off Prine’s debut record; “Lake Marie,” from 1995’s “Lost Dogs and Mixed Blessings,” and seven tracks from his final album, “The Tree of Forgiveness,” including “When I Get to Heaven.” It’s a joyful farewell, in which Prine makes peace with mortality and sings: “When I get to heaven, I’m gonna shake God’s hand/Thank him for more blessings than one man can stand/Then I’m gonna get a guitar and start a rock-n-roll band.”

author: By Mary Williams Walsh
title: Illinois Seeks a Bailout From Congress for Pensions and Cities
description: The president of the State Senate asked for $40 billion to help the pension system, fund unemployment insurance and aid hospitals and cities.
content: Illinois needs more than $40 billion in relief from the federal government because of the coronavirus pandemic — including $10 billion to help bail out its beleaguered pension system, according to a letter the Illinois Senate president sent to members of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Male Infertility: What to Know and How to Cope
description: Infertility is largely thought of as a woman’s issue, but male infertility can affect at least one-third of couples who are struggling to conceive.

description: And how to handle them if they arise.

title: All Babies Cry, but How Much Is Too Much?
description: Babies with colic can be incredibly challenging, but thankfully the condition ends on its own.

title: Vaccine Laws Are Changing. Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: New York is the latest state to end religious exemptions to vaccine requirements as the measles outbreak continues to spread in the United States. Here’s how — and why — vaccination laws are changing.
content: This story was originally published on June 14, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

author: By Meghan MacLean Weir, M.D
title: Your 3-5 Day Old
description: The developmental milestones your 3-day-old is likely to be reaching are the result of months of growth inside the womb. Therefore, what is considered normal for an infant born at 37 weeks may be different for one born at 35 or 39 weeks. And the definition of “normal,” more generally, is changing as well. Prior to 2013, for example, infants born at 37 weeks or later were considered full-term. More recent research, however, suggests that these last few weeks inside mom’s belly may be very important for their development. In 2013, the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology updated its definition of full-term to 39 weeks and discouraged physicians from recommending elective inductions or cesarean sections before then.
content: This story was originally published on April 23, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Your 9-Month-Old
description: You might notice that at 9 months, your baby will likely be establishing herself as an independent human being. She will have preferences and opinions. She will begin understanding that there’s more to the world than what’s in her line of sight at the moment. She is likely mobile, too, crawling and getting ready to stand. While you’ll be excited by all of this, your child is about to enter toddlerhood, which can be an even more demanding time for parents.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Heard-Garris, M.D
title: Your 3-Year-Old
description: Your 3-year-old is growing up quickly and can seem like a walking, talking mini-adult. One of the few reminders of his age might be that he is still in pull-ups. A 3-year-old is starting to get a better sense of the world and how things work within it. His newfound speech and movement skills are not fully refined, and frustrations may lead to more temper tantrums than you are used to, earning him the affectionate title of “three-nager.” Still, 3 is a wonderful age and you will be blown away by your child’s accomplishments.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Survive the Coronavirus Markets
description: One of the worst stretches in market history has included one of the most rapid stock rallies. How can investors get through this ordeal?
content: Financial markets can be bewildering at the best of times. But the coronavirus has made the task of understanding them so much harder.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Germany Starts Broad Antibody Testing to Assess Spread of Coronavirus; Israel Relaxes Restrictions
description: Iran lifts Tehran’s lockdown. Hong Kong arrests pro-democracy figures even as it fights the virus.

author: By Reed Abelson, Sheri Fink, Nicholas Kulish and Katie Thomas
title: An Overlooked, Possibly Fatal Coronavirus Crisis: A Dire Need for Kidney Dialysis
description: Ventilators aren’t the only machines in intensive care units that are in short supply. Doctors have been confronting an unexpected rise in patients with failing kidneys.
content: For weeks, U.S. government officials and hospital executives have warned of a looming shortage of ventilators as the coronavirus pandemic descended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Military Cutting Medevac Flights for Troops in West Africa
description: As Army Green Berets move to confront new threats in the Sahel, the Pentagon is reducing the number of helicopters available for casualty evacuation flights.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States military is sharply reducing its emergency casualty evacuation services in West Africa, raising concerns that American troops on missions there could be left vulnerable if they run into trouble at a time when violence is surging in that corner of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: A Beloved Bar Owner Was Skeptical About the Virus. Then He Took a Cruise.
description: Joe Joyce oversaw JJ Bubbles, a welcoming tavern in a conservative corner of Brooklyn, for 43 years until he died of Covid-19.
content: Decades before he would embark on a cruise to the Mediterranean, confident that the coronavirus would have little to do with him, Joe Joyce was known to the world as a social creature, the kind who would do well on a boat full of strangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: Let’s Play by Our Own Rules in the Pandemic
description: Sports require imagination under quarantine.
content: DURHAM, N.H. — On a recent Saturday, I joined my dad and younger sister in the driveway. It was sunny and brisk out, and we had nothing to do. We were bored of being inside. Without structure and scheduled events — no skating practice, no dance competitions, no track meets or water polo games or taekwondo — the empty stretch that was now our weekends was maddeningly slow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Canapari, M.D
title: How to Sleep Train Your Baby
description: Sleep training is a safe and effective tool to help babies learn to soothe themselves at night.
content: This guide was originally published on May 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson and Kirk Semple
title: U.S. Deported Thousands Amid Covid-19 Outbreak. Some Proved to Be Sick.
description: The U.S. is continuing deportation flights, prompting complaints that some migrants are infected with the coronavirus when they arrive in their home countries.
content: In the scramble to contain the spread of Covid-19 in the United States, the Trump administration has been pushing forward with its aggressive immigration enforcement agenda, deporting thousands of people to their home countries, including some who are sick with the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Germany Starts Broad Antibody Testing to Assess Spread of Coronavirus; Israel Relaxes Restrictions
description: Iran lifts Tehran’s lockdown. Hong Kong arrests pro-democracy figures even as it fights the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Steinberger
title: The Coronavirus Has Put Tennis on Hold. Will Its Spirit Play On?
description: Covid-19 has dealt the sport a tough blow. But how will it impact the ideals that tennis has come to embody?
content: Of all the reasons to grieve right now, the cancellation of a tennis tournament couldn’t be farther down the list. Still, for those of us who find pleasure and succor in tennis, the recent announcement that Wimbledon will not be played this year hit hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: Let’s Play by Our Own Rules in the Pandemic
description: Sports require imagination under quarantine.
content: DURHAM, N.H. — On a recent Saturday, I joined my dad and younger sister in the driveway. It was sunny and brisk out, and we had nothing to do. We were bored of being inside. Without structure and scheduled events — no skating practice, no dance competitions, no track meets or water polo games or taekwondo — the empty stretch that was now our weekends was maddeningly slow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: A Beloved Bar Owner Was Skeptical About the Virus. Then He Took a Cruise.
description: Joe Joyce oversaw JJ Bubbles, a welcoming tavern in a conservative corner of Brooklyn, for 43 years until he died of Covid-19.
content: Decades before he would embark on a cruise to the Mediterranean, confident that the coronavirus would have little to do with him, Joe Joyce was known to the world as a social creature, the kind who would do well on a boat full of strangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson, Sheri Fink, Nicholas Kulish and Katie Thomas
title: An Overlooked, Possibly Fatal Coronavirus Crisis: A Dire Need for Kidney Dialysis
description: Ventilators aren’t the only machines in intensive care units that are in short supply. Doctors have been confronting an unexpected rise in patients with failing kidneys.
content: For weeks, U.S. government officials and hospital executives have warned of a looming shortage of ventilators as the coronavirus pandemic descended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Military Cutting Medevac Flights for Troops in West Africa
description: As Army Green Berets move to confront new threats in the Sahel, the Pentagon is reducing the number of helicopters available for casualty evacuation flights.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States military is sharply reducing its emergency casualty evacuation services in West Africa, raising concerns that American troops on missions there could be left vulnerable if they run into trouble at a time when violence is surging in that corner of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Competitive Marble Racing Finds Fans in a World Missing Sports
description: Videos of the races are meant to be an escape from reality and a distraction from the coronavirus pandemic, organizers say.
content: Professional basketball, soccer and hockey games were suspended. Major League Baseball canceled the start of its season, and the Olympics have been postponed. But at least one sport remains: marble racing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The Food Chain’s Weakest Link: Slaughterhouses
description: A relatively small number of plants process much of the beef and pork in the United States, and some of them have closed because workers are getting sick.
content: The modern American slaughterhouse is a very different place from the one that Upton Sinclair depicted in his early-20th-century novel, “The Jungle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Mullin
title: Everything You Need to Know About Blood Tests During Pregnancy
description: They can reveal valuable health information about you and your baby, but some come with more considerations than others.
content: This guide was originally published on May 13, 2019 in NYT Parenting.

title: The New Rules of Food Allergy Prevention, Testing and Diagnosis

content: This guide was originally published on Aug. 9, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anxious? Yes. But Not About My Son’s Wedding.
description: “If you can get through a global pandemic,” the minister said during the ceremony, “your marriage should be just fine.”
content: A Monday afternoon in St. Louis, gray and brisk, and five people gathered outdoors. It was an outdoor ceremony, like so many are these days, but only because that was the best option for a wedding that had been thrown together in less than 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Olympic Runner’s New Training Partner

source.name: The New York Times

description: Prepare yourself for both positive and negative reactions before sharing your happy news.

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Dallas Homeless Shelter Evacuated After 38 Contract Coronavirus
description: City officials said 164 residents at the privately run shelter, Dallas Life, were taken by bus to a hotel. They will be isolated in individual rooms for two weeks while the shelter is cleaned.
content: A Dallas homeless shelter was evacuated on Friday after 38 residents tested positive for the coronavirus, another example of the pandemic sweeping through one of the nation’s most vulnerable populations.

title: An Elopement Closer to Home
description: They intended to elope — and elope they did — but ended up canceling their original plans and planning a new wedding within just a few days.
content: Anna Davila and Bryce Cole had planned to elope in late March, while in New Orleans to attend the wedding of friends. Their plan was to leave their two children with Ms. Davila’s mother while they took what they told her would be a quick break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: The 10-Foot Theory of Love
description: Anique Hameed and Zachary Graham seemed to always be in the vicinity of the other, even if they weren’t aware of it.
content: When Anique Hameed first saw Zachary Graham, he was standing about 10 feet away from her inside a Washington nightclub.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Does My Baby Have a Speech Delay?

title: Quarantine Cooking With Kids
description: Cooking with children can be educational, fun and delicious.
content: Looking for a project to do with your kid? Of course you are! Provided you can stand a little mess, cook with them. (Or if you have older kids, print out a recipe and set them loose.) Try made-in-the-pan chocolate cake (above), creamy macaroni and cheese, no-bake cookies or any of the more than 50 recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Hall
title: What Does the Good Life Look Like Now?
description: The cappuccinos and hair colorist. The twice-a-week Pilates. The monthly facial. I don’t need all of it.
content: In my isolation, I frequently calculate the cost of my old life. The once-a-week trainer. The twice-a-week Pilates classes. The monthly facial, with the extra laser boost to work on acne scars and wrinkles. The pedicures, as much as I hated them, because who would go around with naked toes? The hair colorist. Regular theater tickets. Daily cappuccinos. Salads at Sweetgreen. Dinners at a perfectly fine but not amazing place for $70 a person, with such intense noise that conversation is prohibited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Trump Is Asking Us to Play Russian Roulette With Our Lives
description: Are we really going to bet that we can go back to life as normal without proper coronavirus tracking in place?
content: “LIBERATE MINNESOTA!” “LIBERATE MICHIGAN!” “LIBERATE VIRGINIA.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr
title: Paul O’Neill, Treasury Secretary Who Clashed With Bush, Dies at 84
description: He was “fearless,” a former colleague said, in pressing ideas based on facts and evidence. His independence cost him his job.
content: Paul H. O’Neill had just presided over a celebrated revival of the aluminum giant Alcoa and was about to begin his retirement in late 2000 with a long drive across the back roads of America in a new Bentley Flying Spur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Violet Moya
title: Sephora Never Valued Workers Like Me
description: I was an ideal employee, but the company treated me terribly, even before it laid me off amid the coronavirus crisis.
content: HOUSTON — In late March, I was suddenly laid off from my job at Sephora, where I’d worked part time for almost two years. The announcement came out of nowhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: Bridging Divides, Most Agree on Economic Outlook: It’s Bleak
description: Even if not directly hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, Americans largely expect unemployment and depression to prevail over the next five years.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has united Americans of different races and income levels in deep pessimism about the economy, in contrast to the widely divergent views that prevailed before the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Your 1-Month-Old
description: At one month, there’s not much for a baby to do besides cry, eat, sleep and poop. You should focus on loving him. Don’t expect much more out of him at this point, but you should still be able to see some progress in development even in the first month.
content: Coordinate her movements. At first, nearly everything your baby does is reflexive. There’s little control. But over time, she should begin to move in more intentional ways — moving her hand to her mouth, for example.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Your 2.5 Year Old
description: At 30 months, your toddler is starting to turn into a person. She likely knows hundreds of words. She’ll sing songs. Instead of one-word demands, she’ll be putting words together in phrases. She’ll also have opinions, which will often differ from yours. She can be a handful, physically, and will be more than able to explore the world on her own.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Peek
title: Is a Nanny Share Right for Your Family?
description: If you need child care part time or want to save on costs, sharing a caregiver may be the way to go.
content: This guide was originally published on Aug. 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting. Check our coverage on what to do about child care during coronavirus here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Of Course!
description: Who wants to go for a ride with Jack Mowat and Jeff Chen?
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Jack Mowat is back — he made a very fun Friday debut last September, which is about 70 quarantine years ago, although somehow he is still 20 years old and a sophomore at the University of Notre Dame. He and his roommate used to solve the daily puzzle on paper every day and line the walls of their room with their handiwork. Looks cute, if you’re tired of staring at your four walls and have access to the real newspaper or a printer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: As Amazon Rises, So Does the Opposition
description: Stacy Mitchell knew that taking on a trillion-dollar company would be a lopsided fight. But the pandemic has not only made Amazon more essential. It has also made it vulnerable.
content: PORTLAND, Maine — A million years ago, Stacy Mitchell was in her office, talking about why Amazon is bad for America.

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Going Too Far
description: Alex Eaton-Salners overdoes it, but we love it.
content: VARIETY PUZZLE — This is a fun diversion that looks like an absolute bear to make, the “Going Too Far” crossword. First of all, there are no closed squares to provide breathing space and flexibility for a constructor, in this case the ingenious Alex Eaton-Salners. On top of that stricture, there is a series of symmetrically arranged gray squares that are filled with a prescribed set of letters that need to figure in one entry, either across or down. The requirements are dizzying to me, but the end result is worth it, a gratifying solve that’s a combination of a straight crossword and a bit of an acrostic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump and the Protesters
description: A reader worries that protesters are putting a higher priority on the economy than on human lives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: The Coronavirus in America: The Year Ahead
description: There will be no quick return to our previous lives, according to nearly two dozen experts. But there is hope for managing the scourge now and in the long term.
content: The coronavirus is spreading from America’s biggest cities to its suburbs, and has begun encroaching on the nation’s rural regions. The virus is believed to have infected millions of citizens and has killed more than 34,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Dozens of Performers Join Global Concert to Benefit Coronavirus Relief
description: “One World: Together at Home,” which kicked off with a six-hour preshow on Saturday, featured Lizzo, Celine Dion, Elton John, Billie Eilish, Lady Gaga, the Rolling Stones and more on prime time.
content: A cross-platform global concert seeking to raise funds for Covid-19 response efforts featured performances by some of the biggest names in music on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Jonathan Martin
title: Gretchen Whitmer Isn’t Backing Down
description: Right-wing protesters, Republican lawmakers and President Trump are attacking the Michigan governor, a possible vice-presidential pick. “I’m not thinking about politics,” she says.
content: She is a first-term governor and rising star in the Democratic Party, a frequent critic of the Trump administration for its handling of the coronavirus health crisis and a prominent foil of the president’s in the heated debate over when to reopen the nation for business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: No Fight Over Red Ink Now, but Virus Spending Will Force Tough Choices
description: The surge of deficit spending to “never-before-seen levels” is viewed as necessary, but dangerous for the future.
content: WASHINGTON — The deficit hawks have had their wings clipped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Simon Marks
title: 10 African Countries Have No Ventilators. That’s Only Part of the Problem.
description: Basic supplies like oxygen and soap are needed first to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — South Sudan, a nation of 11 million, has more vice presidents (five) than ventilators (four). The Central African Republic has three ventilators for its five million people. In Liberia, which is similar in size, there are six working machines — and one of them sits behind the gates of the United States Embassy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Raphael Minder
title: In Spain, a Call to ‘Free Our Children’ From Coronavirus Confinement
description: The strictest lockdown measures in Europe have left countless children bored, exhausted and sometimes depressed.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — For five weeks, Lia Aparicio Cenador hasn’t been outside once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: The Return of Barack Obama
description: Many young progressives, conflicted about the former president’s legacy, welcomed his re-emergence this week.
content: On Tuesday, in a 12-minute video, former President Barack Obama re-emerged from his primary season dormancy to formally endorse Joe Biden, his former vice president and his party’s presumptive nominee. Millions tuned in online, nostalgic for the ballast of his familiar cadence. Many huddled at home as a global pandemic — one that in 2014 he warned could arrive — wreaks havoc, taking lives and evaporating livelihoods. The endorsement had the air of a warm-up; an act one, scene one in the effort to “make the case for Biden that Biden has had trouble making himself,” as Politico recently put it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Who Owes You a Refund? Should You Even Ask?
description: Airlines? For sure. Vrbo? Probably. But what about your child’s summer camp?
content: Among the financially unlucky right now, one question reigns supreme: Which bills can I simply not pay and for how long?

title: New York Appears to Be ‘Past the Plateau’ of Virus Cases, Cuomo Says
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo backed away from his conflict with President Trump but emphasized that the state would need federal help on testing.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo arrived to his daily coronavirus briefing in Albany, N.Y., on Saturday with cautionary good news: The state has continued to make progress in its battle with a virus that has killed more than 13,000 residents, enough people to populate an upstate small city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: After Virus Delays, Census Must Scramble to Avoid Undercount
description: Slammed by a pandemic, the Census Bureau postponed crucial portions of the count for the third time in a month, further raising the bar for an accurate count.
content: WASHINGTON — Barely a month into the 2020 census, the 1,600 residents of Tract 1847 in Royal Oak, Mich., a comfortable Detroit suburb, are taking the rest of the country to school. Nationally, half of all households have filled out their census forms. Royal Oak is up to seven in 10, virtually all of them filing online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Gallagher
title: A Father’s Impossible Promise
description: “It’s not always like this,” I told my newborn son. But I don’t know what he will face in his lifetime.
content: In June 2017, hours after I’d held my newborn boy for the first time, a rental van accelerated onto a London Bridge walkway and ran over as many pedestrians as it could. When the van crashed, its occupants got out and began attacking civilians with knives. The three ISIS terrorists were soon shot dead by the police, leaving eight killed and 48 wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Return for Baseball Would Require a New Debate
description: On the bright side, if M.L.B. and the players’ union need to fight over the details about a return to play, it would mean such a return is possible.
content: Everybody wants a baseball season. Nobody knows quite how that will look amid the coronavirus pandemic. Those are the only certainties for a sport that has an unbroken chain of seasons with at least 100 games stretching back to the 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Your 4-Month-Old
description: You might notice that at 4 months, your baby’s social skills are developing rapidly; he is learning how to interact socially with people and physically with the environment. He may also be starting to get better at using his hands to grab things and, perhaps, rolling over on his own.
content: Your baby is learning how to use his “equipment.” He can not only see a toy on the ground, for example, but can recognize it, reach for it and grab it himself. He is not just reacting to noises and sounds reflexively, but is starting to “talk back,” so to speak, mimicking the tones he hears and using those sounds to communicate his wants and needs. Babies have all the tools (think hardware) necessary to learn language, but they’re laying down the neural pathways (think software) to learn how to use it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Your 6-Month-Old
description: At 6 months, your baby is probably starting to show some situational awareness. She knows the difference between a parent and a stranger, and enjoys seeing herself in a mirror. She can respond to her name, have “conversations” with you consisting of sounds, and is probably rolling over and sitting without support (or at least getting close to doing so).
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan MacLean Weir, M.D
title: Your 15-Month-Old
description: Pediatricians love reminding anyone who will listen that children aren’t little adults. Even so, by the time your child reaches 15 months, there’s a good chance you’ll start seeing glimmers of the person he or she will eventually become. While this age brings great leaps in all areas of development (motor, speech-language, cognitive and social-emotional), you’ll also notice that your child’s personality largely dictates which skills he’ll focus on mastering.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Heard-Garris, M.D
title: Your 5-Year-Old
description: Though she might be the baby of the family, you have a big kid now. Your child is like a curious scientist, exploring and questioning the world around her. She has likely been inundating you with questions about “why” and “how.” Their curious minds make 5-year-olds great problem solvers and typically ready to learn as they enter kindergarten. At 5 years old, children can create entire fantasy worlds through their imaginative and dramatic play.
content: This story was originally published on April 22, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Wedding on the Perfect Date, After 20 Years Together
description: Everything came together for the couple, just before the lockdown took place.
content: Erica Hubbard waited a long time to get married to Nevin King. Had she waited any longer, she’s not sure they would be married today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Dozens of Performers Join Global Concert to Benefit Coronavirus Relief
description: “One World: Together at Home,” which kicked off with a six-hour preshow on Saturday, featured Lizzo, Celine Dion, Elton John, Billie Eilish, Lady Gaga, the Rolling Stones and more on prime time.
content: A cross-platform global concert seeking to raise funds for Covid-19 response efforts featured performances by some of the biggest names in music on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: The Return of Barack Obama
description: Many young progressives, conflicted about the former president’s legacy, welcomed his re-emergence this week.
content: On Tuesday, in a 12-minute video, former President Barack Obama re-emerged from his primary season dormancy to formally endorse Joe Biden, his former vice president and his party’s presumptive nominee. Millions tuned in online, nostalgic for the ballast of his familiar cadence. Many huddled at home as a global pandemic — one that in 2014 he warned could arrive — wreaks havoc, taking lives and evaporating livelihoods. The endorsement had the air of a warm-up; an act one, scene one in the effort to “make the case for Biden that Biden has had trouble making himself,” as Politico recently put it.
source.name: The New York Times
